qas.question: What is a fine, tightly twisted type of cotton fabric?
What is lisle considered to be as a fabric?
What does extra twisting of lisle thread produce?
Where was the lisle thread originally made?
How is color perceived to be for lisle in comparison to softer yarns?
What is a fine, tightly twisted type of cotton glove?
What is lisle considered to be as a city?
What does extra twisting of gloves produce?
How is color perceived to be for gloves in comparison with stockings?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Cotton lisle<b5_0/><a0_0/> is a finely-spun, tightly twisted type of cotton that is noted for being <a1_0><b6_0>strong and durable<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Lisle is composed of two strands that have each been twisted an extra twist per inch than ordinary yarns and combined to create a <a2_0><b7_0>single thread<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The yarn is spun so that it is compact and solid. This cotton is used mainly for underwear, stockings, and gloves. Colors applied to this yarn are noted for being <a4_0><b9_0>more brilliant<b9_0/><a4_0/> than colors applied to softer yarn. This type of thread was first made in the city of <a3_0><b8_0>Lisle, France<b8_0/><a3_0/> (now Lille), hence its name.
